facts.claim: The volatility surface represents the volatility of all options across all strikes and all expirations for a single symbol

Backwardation occurs when short-term IVs exceed long-term IVs
Out-of-the-money calls display elevated implied volatility compared to in-the-money calls, resembling a flattened J pattern
Out-of-the-money puts show higher implied volatility than in-the-money puts, reflecting market dynamics where underlying equity prices tend to fall faster than they rise
The SMV curve synthesizes call and put information while accounting for arbitrage relationships, enabling more precise skew analysis than selecting between call or put skews independently
The volatility smile is a U-shaped pattern where at-the-money implied volatility remains lower than further delta strikes
Slope quantifies skew steepness and lopsidedness by drawing a tangent line at the 50-delta point and measuring direction and magnitude
